title: TomPegden published Brexit forces EHL to put expansion plans on hold
text:
Brexit forces EHL to put expansion plans on hold By TomPegden | Posted: July 12, 2016 1 COMMENTS SHARES Mike Sewell Andrew Robinson (head of employment), Jason Hathaway (group MD), Rik Pancholi (head of EHL commercial) and Ian Morris (group commercial director) Brexit forces EHL to put expansion plans on hold X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Pictures: Mike Sewell Andrew Robinson (head of employment), Jason Hathaway (group MD), Rik Pancholi (head of EHL commercial) and Ian Morris... Comments (1) 
A high street law firm is putting its "aggressive" expansion plans on hold in light of the Brexit vote. 
Edward Hands and Lewis (EHL) has paused plans for a new branch in Birstall and for three other offices which were in early negotiations. 
The firm, based in Loughborough Road, Belgrave, has also made seven redundancies and closed a call handling operation. 
Senior partner Jason Hathaway said taking stock after swift expansion was the right thing to do in the current uncertain market. 
He said the decision to take a more cautious approach was made at a board meeting the Monday after the Brexit vote. 
The firm pulled the Birstall office deal the next day – refitting new offices and bringing in staff costs the firm in the region of £100,000. 
Mr Hathaway said staff had been reassured that the business was on a sound footing and was still recruiting in other areas. 
The fundamental principle of creating a strong high street brand, he said, was still in place. 
EHL has 154 staff and 15 offices including new branches in Hinckley, Oadby and Beeston, Notts. 
Its push for growth on the high street has seen turnover grow from £4.8 million to £6.5 million in a year. 
Mr Hathaway said: "We had a vision to have 50 offices by 2020, and have pulled the plug on that vision. 
"It was based on the expectation that the economy would grow and we do not now forecast that huge growth in the economy. 
"I still believe in building a high street brand, but the focus is on building a strong business and putting our resources into that and not pursuing our aggressive growth strategy. 
"If we had stayed in the EU there would have been a bounce – the Bank of England had forecast 2 per cent growth but is now forecasting marginal growth, and some are saying recession. 
"There is a potential slowing down of the property market. On the commercial side we are seeing businesses delaying decisions. 
"We are simply saying we can't make a commitment to opening branches because the world has changed. 
"The UK economy has had a seismic shift and we have to respond. 
"As a consequence we have reviewed our growth strategy which has resulted in some positions within the business being looked at and some people have been let go." 
He said one person had gone from a call centre in Leicester, and another four had been relocated. 
The business has also lost a couple of conveyancing roles, a paralegal and a handful of administrative roles. 
It is also shutting a serviced office in Bromborough in the Wirral after deciding not to replace a conveyancer and two other staff who quit the firm last month. 
Mr Hathaway said expansion could get back on track if a new Prime Minster was able to negotiate a good deal with Europe and bring confidence back to the economy. 
He said: "Where we have got offices we are investing to build them up to our model and will continue that." 
He said a new commercial office in Leicester with 16 staff was doing well, and property work in London had been brisk thanks to a "big increase" in overseas buyers after the value of sterling dropped.
